    LR

    LR.Rmd
    library(LR)
#> 
#> Attaching package: 'LR'
#> The following object is masked from 'package:datasets':
#> 
#>     state.x77
library(bench)

    How to use this package

    Users need to prepare two data sets as prediction variables(X) and outcome variable(Y) respectively. The former one is a numerical matrix, where each row represents an observation and each column represents a prediction variable (intercept should not be included). The latter is a column vector (or a n by 1 numerical matrix) representing the outcome variable.

    (1) Fit a simple linear regression model:

    We can obtain the the point estimates, standard errors, t values for partial test, and corresponding p-value of the coefficients of the simple linear regression.

    y <- as.matrix(state.x77$`Life Exp`)
colnames(y) <- "Life Exp"
x <- as.matrix(state.x77$Murder)
colnames(x) <- "Murder"
SLR.model <- lr(y, x)
print(SLR.model$Coefficents)
#>          Estimate Std. Error    t value     Pr(>|t|)
#>        72.9735623 0.26997402 270.298463 0.000000e+00
#> Murder -0.2839472 0.03278988  -8.659599 2.260059e-11

    (2) Fit a mutiple linear regression model:

    We can obtain the the point estimates, standard errors, t values for partial test, and corresponding p-value of the coefficients of the simple linear regression.

    y <- as.matrix(state.x77$`Life Exp`)
colnames(y) <- "Life Exp"
x <- as.matrix(state.x77[,c(1:3, 5:8)])
MLR.model <- lr(y, x)
print(MLR.model$Coefficents)
#>                 Estimate   Std. Error     t value     Pr(>|t|)
#>             7.094322e+01 1.747975e+00 40.58594017 0.000000e+00
#> Population  5.180036e-05 2.918703e-05  1.77477309 8.318351e-02
#> Income     -2.180424e-05 2.444256e-04 -0.08920603 9.293422e-01
#> Illiteracy  3.382032e-02 3.662799e-01  0.09233464 9.268712e-01
#> Murder     -3.011232e-01 4.662073e-02 -6.45899735 8.679582e-08
#> HS Grad     4.892948e-02 2.332328e-02  2.09788176 4.197175e-02
#> Frost      -5.735001e-03 3.143230e-03 -1.82455682 7.518682e-02
#> Area       -7.383166e-08 1.668163e-06 -0.04425927 9.649075e-01

    (3) Calculate the 95% confidence interval of \(\beta\)’s:

    We can get the lower and upper bound of the confidence interval, with default confidence level of 0.95.

    CI.95 <- lr(y, x, CI = TRUE, CI.level = 0.95)$Confidence_Interval
print(CI.95)
#>                    Lower         Upper
#>             6.741567e+01  7.447078e+01
#> Population -7.101457e-06  1.107022e-04
#> Income     -5.150751e-04  4.714666e-04
#> Illiteracy -7.053624e-01  7.730031e-01
#> Murder     -3.952076e-01 -2.070387e-01
#> HS Grad     1.861199e-03  9.599776e-02
#> Frost      -1.207830e-02  6.082932e-04
#> Area       -3.440321e-06  3.292657e-06

    (4) Calculate \(R^2\) and adjusted \(R^2\) of linear model:

    r.square <- lr(y, x)$R_squared[[1]]
adjusted.r.square <- lr(y, x)$R_squared[[2]]
print(r.square)
#> [1] 0.7361563
print(adjusted.r.square)
#> [1] 0.6921823

    (5) Calculate the F value for overall F test and the corresponding p-value.

    F.stat <- lr(y, x)$F_statistics
print(F.stat)
#>          F statistics      p value df.ssr df.sse
#> Life Exp     16.74073 2.534328e-10      7     42

    (6) Use Rcpp to improve efficiency

    lr.Rcpp <- lr(y, x, Rcpp = T)
print(lr.Rcpp)
#> $Coefficents
#>        Estimate   Std. Error     t value     Pr(>|t|)
#> 1  7.094322e+01 1.747975e+00 40.58594017 0.000000e+00
#> 2  5.180036e-05 2.918703e-05  1.77477309 7.593536e-02
#> 3 -2.180424e-05 2.444256e-04 -0.08920603 9.289182e-01
#> 4  3.382032e-02 3.662799e-01  0.09233464 9.264322e-01
#> 5 -3.011232e-01 4.662073e-02 -6.45899735 1.053990e-10
#> 6  4.892948e-02 2.332328e-02  2.09788176 3.591559e-02
#> 7 -5.735001e-03 3.143230e-03 -1.82455682 6.806794e-02
#> 8 -7.383166e-08 1.668163e-06 -0.04425927 9.646977e-01
#> 
#> $Confidence_Interval
#>           Lower         Upper
#> 1  6.741567e+01  7.447078e+01
#> 2 -7.101457e-06  1.107022e-04
#> 3 -5.150751e-04  4.714666e-04
#> 4 -7.053624e-01  7.730031e-01
#> 5 -3.952076e-01 -2.070387e-01
#> 6  1.861199e-03  9.599776e-02
#> 7 -1.207830e-02  6.082932e-04
#> 8 -3.440321e-06  3.292657e-06
#> 
#> $R_squared
#>      Multiple_R_squared Adjusted_R_squared
#> [1,]          0.7361563          0.6921823
#> 
#> $F_statistics
#>      F statistics      p value df.ssr df.sse
#> [1,]     16.74073 2.534328e-10      7     42

    compare my function with “lm()” function 

    X <- matrix(rnorm(500), ncol = 5)
beta <- runif(5)
Y <- X %*% beta + rnorm(100, sd = 0.1)
  
 
compare <- bench::mark(myfun = {
  coefs.actual <- as.vector(lr(Y, X)$Coefficents[, 1])
}, lm.fun = {
   coefs.expected <- as.vector(lm(Y ~ X)$coefficients)
})
summary(compare)
#> # A tibble: 2 × 6
#>   expression      min   median `itr/sec` mem_alloc `gc/sec`
#>   <bch:expr> <bch:tm> <bch:tm>     <dbl> <bch:byt>    <dbl>
#> 1 myfun         215µs    229µs     3970.      32KB     13.3
#> 2 lm.fun        552µs    580µs     1608.     525KB     17.1

    compare cpp function efficiency in my code 

    X <- matrix(rnorm(5000), ncol = 50)
beta <- runif(50)
Y <- X %*% beta + rnorm(100, sd = 0.1)
  
 
compare.Rcpp <- bench::mark(
  myfun.useRcpp = {
  coefs.wRcpp <- as.vector(lr(Y, X, Rcpp = T)$Coefficents[, 1])
}, lm.fun = {
  coefs.noRcpp <- as.vector(lr(Y, X, Rcpp = F)$Coefficents[, 1])
})
summary(compare.Rcpp)
#> # A tibble: 2 × 6
#>   expression         min   median `itr/sec` mem_alloc `gc/sec`
#>   <bch:expr>    <bch:tm> <bch:tm>     <dbl> <bch:byt>    <dbl>
#> 1 myfun.useRcpp    400µs  429.3µs     2175.    55.5KB     6.23
#> 2 lm.fun           1.1ms   1.26ms      754.   383.7KB     4.15

    we can observe that while we use the Rcpp version of my code, the efficiency will improve a lot.
